description: From Middle English daywork, daywerk, from Old English dæġweorc, from Proto-West Germanic *dagawerk, from Proto-Germanic *dagawerką, equivalent to day +‎ work.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The work done in a day; a day's work. [10th–19th c.]
(obsolete) The amount of land that can be worked in a day. [14th–17th c.]
Work carried out or paid for on a daily basis; day labour. [from 16th c.]
Work done during the day; specifically, the cover-work carried out by someone involved in intelligence work, as opposed to their secret activities.
examples: ‘The task of servicing such moles is not entrusted to normal overseas residencies but to a Karla representative, as he is known, usually a military officer, whose daywork is to be an attaché of an Embassy.’
